headline: The Ebola Soccer Survivors
abstract: Struggling in the shadow of Ebola, survivors of the disease in Sierra Leone found new strength and solidarity on the soccer field.

headline: W.H.O. Sees Ebola Slowing in Liberia
abstract: The World Health Organization said there had been no increases in laboratory-confirmed cases of Ebola in the country.

headline: W.H.O. Update on Ebola Epidemic
abstract: Dr. Bruce Aylward, the World Health Organization’s assistant director general, said the number of Ebola cases worldwide will rise above 9,000 this week.

headline: Treating Ebola: The Hunt for a Drug
abstract: Although there are currently no drugs or vaccines approved in the United States to treat or prevent Ebola, health officials have used several experimental drugs in the recent epidemic.

headline: Spain’s Premier on Ebola Crisis
abstract: Prime Minister Mariano Rajoy of Spain addressed his country’s Congress on the Ebola threat, as health authorities have confirmed that two others suspected of having the virus have tested negative.

headline: Spanish Hospital on Ebola-Infected Nurse
abstract: Staff members at Carlos III Hospital in Madrid discussed how they were stemming the spread of Ebola after a Spanish nurse contracted the virus.

headline: Putting On Ebola Protection Gear
abstract: To enter the Ebola ward in Suakoko, doctors must dress in a sealed protection suit resistant to splashes and punctures. No skin can be left exposed. Dr. Colin Banks demonstrates the process.

headline: W.H.O. Declares Liberia Ebola Free
abstract: Representatives from the World Health Organization said that no cases of the Ebola virus had emerged in two incubation cycles, meaning Guinea, Liberia and Sierra Leone are Ebola free.

headline: Sirleaf Speaks on Ebola Outbreak
abstract: President Ellen Johnson Sirleaf of Liberia talked about flaws in the Liberian health care system and rebuilding it after the Ebola epidemic.

headline: Erison and the Ebola Soccer Survivors
abstract: Refusing to live in Ebola’s shadow, Erison Turay and others in Sierra Leone found new strength and solidarity on the soccer field.

headline: Ebola Patient in Germany Dies
abstract: Bernhard Ruf, the chief physician in the Department of Infectious Diseases at Leipzig’s St. Georg Clinic, issued a statement after the death of an Ebola patient who underwent treatment in Germany.

headline: Liberia Confirms New Ebola Case
abstract: Dr. Bernice Dahn, Liberia’s new minister of health, said on Tuesday that the country had confirmed its first case of Ebola since it was declared free of the virus more than a month ago.

headline: Fighting Ebola Outbreak Street by Street
abstract: Some ambulance workers in Monrovia have been infected with Ebola, while others have been attacked for not getting to patients in time.

headline: W.H.O. Discusses Latest Ebola Numbers
abstract: Dr. Keiji Fukuda, an assistant director-general for the World Health Organization, said that the situation in Guinea, Liberia and Sierra Leone was still of “great concern.”

headline: Ebola Protection Gear Safety
abstract: To enter the Ebola ward at an International Medical Corps clinic in Suakoko, Liberia, doctors dress in a sealed protection suit. Dr. Colin Bucks, a physician working there, demonstrates the process.

headline: African Nations Win Fight Against Ebola
abstract: A representative from the World Health Organization announced that the countries of Guinea, Liberia and Sierra Leone have stopped the “original chains of transmission” of the Ebola virus.

headline: Ebola-Free Spanish Nurse Speaks Out
abstract: María Teresa Romero Ramos, a Spanish auxiliary nurse who was the first person to be infected by Ebola outside of Africa, spoke after she was released from Carlos III hospital in Madrid.

headline: W.H.O. Officials Report a Drop in New Ebola Cases
abstract: The World Health Organization reported the lowest weekly total of new cases in the West Africa Ebola epidemic this year, calling it an encouraging development but expressing caution about complacency.

headline: Ebola’s Other Victim: West Africa’s Economy
abstract: In Sierra Leone, Guinea and Liberia, Ebola is not just affecting immune systems but also the bottom lines of businesses and governments.

headline: Times Coverage of Ebola: Pulitzer-Winning Articles and More
abstract: The Times produced more than 400 articles, including about 50 front-page stories from inside the Ebola-afflicted countries themselves. Here is a sample of work.

headline: U.N. Employee Under Treatment for Ebola in France
abstract: The health ministry said in a statement on its website that the patient had contracted the virus in Sierra Leone and was being treated in a military hospital near Paris.

headline: Signs Ebola Spreads in Sex Prompt a C.D.C. Warning
abstract: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention urged caution for Ebola survivors after a man might have passed the virus to his partner months after recovering from it.

headline: Health Agency Reports Lowest Weekly Total of New Ebola Cases
abstract: The World Health Organization on Wednesday reported the lowest weekly total of new Ebola cases so far this year in the three nations of West Africa that have been afflicted by the deadly virus.

headline: Ebola Flare-Up Has Ended in Sierra Leone, W.H.O. Says
abstract: The World Health Organization said two incubation periods – or 42 days – had passed since the last known victim had tested negative for the deadly virus.

headline: Leaders of Ebola Fight at U.N. Express Worry About Eradication
abstract: The top two health officials managing the Ebola epidemic cast doubt on a pledge by West African leaders to reduce new cases to zero by mid-April.

headline: Ebola Cases Increase in Guinea
abstract: The World Health Organization said Wednesday that 95 new cases of Ebola had been confirmed in Guinea in the week that ended last Sunday, the highest weekly total for that country so far this year.

headline: W.H.O. Declares Nigeria Free of Ebola
abstract: Rui Gama Vaz, a World Health Organization representative in Nigeria, and the country’s health minister, Dr. Onyebuchi Chukwu, discussed the news that the country was free of the Ebola virus.

headline: Americans Evacuated From Sierra Leone After Possible Ebola Contact
abstract: The group of 10 aid workers, with the group Partners in Health, may have come in contact with the virus in Sierra Leone, officials said.

headline: As Ebola Rages in Sierra Leone, a Lonely Death
abstract: While health officials are making headway against the Ebola epidemic in neighboring Liberia, the disease is still rampant here, despite a big international push.

headline: British Nurse With Ebola Is Improving, Hospital Says
abstract: The nurse, Pauline Cafferkey, who was infected while working as a volunteer in Sierra Leone, “is showing signs of improvement,” the Royal Free Hospital said.

headline: Obama Says U.S. Work on Ebola Isn’t Done
abstract: President Obama said that although all but 100 of the American troops deployed to West Africa to help manage the Ebola outbreak will be coming home by April 30, the civilian response will be expanded.

headline: Liberia: Ebola-Free, for a Second Time
abstract: The World Health Organization declared Liberia free of Ebola for a second time on Thursday, several months after it was first thought to have halted the virus in May.

headline: Inside the Ebola Ward
abstract: Workers at the International Medical Corps treatment center in Suakoko, Liberia, use faith, hard work and caution as they face a stream of sick people in this remote hilltop east of Monrovia.

headline: Sierra Leone: Ebola Trial Begins
abstract: Researchers began vaccinating volunteers in Sierra Leone on Monday with an experimental Ebola vaccine.

headline: Scottish Nurse Pauline Cafferkey Recovers From Ebola for 2nd Time
abstract: Ms. Cafferkey contracted Ebola last year while doing charity work in Sierra Leone and recovered for the first time in January. Last month, she again fell critically ill.

headline: Liberia: Ebola Stalls Birth Registrations
abstract: The births of more than 70,000 children in Liberia during the Ebola crisis were never recorded, leaving them vulnerable to marginalization.

headline: Liberia: 200 Reportedly Had Contact With Ebola Victim
abstract: The World Health Organization reported Friday that nearly 200 people had been in contact with a 17-year-old in Liberia who was confirmed to have died of Ebola.

headline: Three Hopes for an Ebola Treatment
abstract: With thousands infected with the Ebola virus, millions of dollars are being pledged to develop treatment options. Three avenues that have potential but are a long way from being viable treatments.

headline: Ebola Suspected in U.N. Worker’s Death
abstract: The victim was Liberian who had worked for the United Nations peacekeeping mission in her country.

headline: Ebola’s Economic Cost Re-Examined
abstract: The World Bank chief economist for Africa said the cost may be $3 billion or $4 billion, not the worst-case outcome of more than $32 billion.

headline: U.N. Secretary General to Visit Ebola-Plagued Nations
abstract: The trip, which is to begin later this week, seems designed to send a message of solidarity with the three affected countries: Guinea, Liberia and Sierra Leone.

headline: Day After a Victory Over Ebola, Sierra Leone Reports a Death
abstract: A 22-year-old woman from the northern part of the country was identified as the victim, and certain areas would be quarantined in response to her death.

headline: An American With Ebola Is Improving
abstract: An American aid worker being treated for Ebola at the National Institutes of Health clinical center in Maryland is doing better and has been upgraded from critical to serious condition, the N.I.H. announced Thursday.

headline: Liberia Reports First Ebola Case in Weeks
abstract: Confirmation that a patient tested positive deflated hope that Liberia was now free of the Ebola virus.

headline: Liberia Recommends Ebola Survivors Practice Safe Sex Indefinitely
abstract: After an Ebola death, scientists want to gather more information on the length of time the virus might remain present in semen.

headline: Another Ebola Fatality Is Reported in Liberia
abstract: A woman died at an Ebola treatment unit in Liberia, the second victim of the virus since the World Health Organization declared the country free of of the virus in May.

headline: Q. and A. With Sheri Fink on Covering Ebola in Liberia
abstract: Sheri Fink, a New York Times reporter and a physician, answers readers’ questions about the Ebola crisis in rural Liberia.

headline: Mali: New Ebola Case Is Confirmed as Response to First Was Wrapping Up
abstract: Mali, which was just coming to the end of 21-day quarantines for 108 people linked to its first Ebola case, now has a second, the government announced Tuesday.

headline: Ebola Risks Linger, Officials Warn
abstract: Top United Nations officials on Wednesday warned against complacency over the waning Ebola epidemic in three West African countries.

headline: Children With No Place to Go
abstract: The United Nations estimates that 10,000 children have been orphaned in countries affected by Ebola. Many are stigmatized and shunned by their own communities.

headline: Guinea, Last Nation With Ebola, May Soon Be Declared Free of Virus
abstract: A 3-week-old girl now recovering could be the final patient in an epidemic that killed more than 11,300 people, overwhelmingly in West Africa.

headline: American and British Aid Workers Infected With Ebola in Sierra Leone
abstract: The new infections were a reminder that the Ebola crisis that has ravaged West Africa is far from over.

headline: No New Ebola Cases Were Reported in the Past Week, Health Agency Says
abstract: The World Health Organization has warned that Ebola could still come back because more than 500 people in Guinea who may have been exposed are still being monitored.

headline: New Ebola Cases Decline, but W.H.O. Advises Caution
abstract: Seven new cases of Ebola were reported in Guinea and Sierra Leone last week, the lowest weekly total in more than a year.

headline: 2014 Goals for Ebola Treatment May Not Be Met, U.N. Health Officials Say
abstract: A senior World Health Organization official for Ebola response said Monday that year-end goals of isolating and treating all patients and safely burying the dead would be major challenges.

headline: Ebola Survivor From Scotland Is Critically Ill
abstract: The case of the nurse, Pauline Cafferkey, points to how much is still unknown about the virus and its long-term effects.

headline: Liberia Bans Election Rallies to Fight Ebola
abstract: In issuing the crowd-control order, President Ellen Johnson Sirleaf argued that large concentrations of people at election rallies were precisely the situations that could spawn new infections.

headline: Sierra Leone Defends Jailing Critic of Ebola Response
abstract: The attorney general in Sierra Leone said a prominent radio journalist had undermined the government’s effort to stop the disease’s spread.

headline: Empty Ebola Clinics in Liberia Are Seen as Misstep in U.S. Relief Effort
abstract: After the U.S. spent hundreds of millions of dollars and deployed nearly 3,000 troops, only 28 Ebola patients have been treated at the 11 centers built by the American military in Liberia.

headline: Malaria Scourge Has Declined Globally, but Ebola May Affect Toll, W.H.O. Says
abstract: The World Health Organization reported steep declines in malaria cases and deaths compared with 2000 in a report released early Tuesday, saying the progress was particularly notable in Africa, where the disease is most prevalent.

headline: Agencies Warn of Hunger in Ebola Zone
abstract: The Ebola outbreak ravaging West Africa could double the number of people facing hunger in the three worst-affected countries to more than one million by March, two United Nations agencies warned Wednesday.

headline: Video: Inside the Ebola Ward
abstract: The daily challenges faced by doctors, nurses and other workers at the Ebola treatment center run by the International Medical Corps in Bong County, Liberia.

headline: As Ebola Retreats, Obama Urges Vigilance and Preparation in West Africa
abstract: During a visit to Washington by the leaders of Guinea, Liberia and Sierra Leone, President Obama said the global response must continue.

headline: Obama to Recall Military Personnel From Ebola Zone, Officials Say
abstract: The president will also outline new steps aimed at eradicating the disease now that the crisis in West Africa has eased, the officials said.

headline: Report Traces Ebola’s Spread in Liberia
abstract: The height of the epidemic in Liberia can be traced back to a single case of the disease probably introduced from Sierra Leone.

headline: Europe Evaluates Ebola Measures as Possibility of New Cases Arises in France and Spain
abstract: As new patients were evaluated, officials discussed whether proper preventive measures were being taken.

headline: More Than 10,000 Africa Ebola Cases, Health Agency Says
abstract: A total of 10,141 people had contracted the disease worldwide, the World Health Organization said in its latest update on the progress of the epidemic.

headline: Condition of British Ebola Patient Worsens
abstract: Doctors treating Pauline Cafferkey, a Scottish nurse who was found to have Ebola after returning from volunteer work in Sierra Leone, say that her condition has deteriorated to critical.

headline: India Isolates Ebola Survivor at an Airport
abstract: The man was successfully treated in Liberia, and blood tests after he flew home were negative, but signs of the virus were found lingering in his semen.

headline: Liberia’s President Urges U.S. to Continue Ebola Aid
abstract: President Ellen Johnson Sirleaf of Liberia praised the American efforts to fight the virus, which have helped to nearly eliminate new cases.

headline: Doctors Link Risky Burials to Ebola Rise in West Africa
abstract: Officials at the World Health Organization said that there had been a nearly fourfold increase during the most recent week of reporting, to about 35 new cases.

headline: U.N. Seeks a More Nimble Response to Ebola in Africa
abstract: The organization has struggled to keep up with the spread and decline of the disease in specific localities.

headline: W.H.O. Assails Delay in Ebola Vaccine
abstract: Dr. Margaret Chan, the director general of the health organization, said the drug industry’s drive for profit was one reason no vaccine had yet been found for Ebola.

headline: Spanish Nurse Is Declared Free of Ebola
abstract: Four straight tests administered to an auxiliary nurse, María Teresa Romero Ramos, have come back negative for the virus, hospital officials said.

headline: A Photographer Documents Ebola’s Deadly Spread
abstract: A collection of work by the photographer Daniel Berehulak, who has been capturing lives touched by the Ebola virus across West Africa since August.

headline: Vaccines Face Same Mistrust That Fed Ebola
abstract: The same mix of fear and distrust that helped the Ebola epidemic spread is hampering doctors conducting trials on new medicines.

headline: In Guinea, a Hard-Won ‘Victory’ Over Ebola
abstract: The country now enters a three-month period of heightened surveillance during which the virus could re-emerge, as it has done twice in Liberia after it ended transmission.

headline: Ebola Cases in 3 Family Members Confirmed in Liberia
abstract: The first documented case is a 15-year-old boy, and it comes two months after the country was declared free of the virus for the second time.

headline: Sierra Leone Declared Free of Ebola Transmissions
abstract: The news marks a joyous but tense moment in Sierra Leone, where Ebola has crippled the nation’s economy and officials worry the virus could re-emerge at any moment.

headline: Officials Revise Goals on Containing Ebola After Signs of Wider Exposure in Mali
abstract: The leaders of the United Nations and the World Health Organization said nearly 500 people in Mali and Guinea had been exposed to a sickened imam who had been misdiagnosed.

headline: How to Help Sweetie Sweetie
abstract: The home where Sweetie Sweetie is staying is sponsored by ChildFund International, a private aid agency.

headline: Panel Calls W.H.O. Unfit to Handle a Crisis Like Ebola
abstract: An independent panel said in a report released Tuesday that the World Health Organization was sluggish, financially unprepared and overly reliant on “good diplomacy.”

headline: In Conspicuous Success, Senegal Is Declared Ebola-Free
abstract: Senegal’s achievement came as the virus rampaged in neighboring countries and contagion alarm continued to mount.

headline: Britain to Screen for Ebola Amid Possible New Cases in Europe
abstract: Britain said it would introduce measures at airports and rail terminals to screen passengers from affected countries as concerns over Ebola grew in Europe.

headline: Obama Hosts Liberian President Sirleaf
abstract: President Obama praised Ellen Johnson Sirleaf, the Liberian president, for her leadership during the Ebola epidemic. Ms. Sirleaf thanked Mr. Obama for his response to the crisis.

headline: Exposure Concerns Grow in Liberia After Diagnosis of First Ebola Case in Weeks
abstract: The patient, a street vendor who lived in a one-bathroom house shared with 52 others in a Monrovia suburb, had sold food last week at a school where more than 1,900 students are enrolled.

headline: Liberia Is Declared Free of Ebola, but Officials Sound Note of Caution
abstract: The announcement Saturday made Liberia the first of the hardest-hit West African countries, including Guinea and Sierra Leone, to bring a formal end to the epidemic.

headline: Liberia Will Proceed With Senate Vote Delayed by Ebola
abstract: An election repeatedly delayed because of the epidemic and other challenges will be held on Saturday, but critics worry whether voting will fair and safe.

headline: Ebola Now Preoccupies Once-Skeptical Leader in Guinea
abstract: President Alpha Condé, whose bureaucracy once played down the Ebola epidemic to avoid scaring investors, has become aggressively involved in the fight.

headline: New U.N. Ebola Trust Fund Falls Far Short of Goal
abstract: Secretary General Ban Ki-moon said the new fund had received a fraction of the nearly $1 billion needed.

headline: Deadliest Ebola Outbreak on Record Is Over, W.H.O. Says
abstract: The announcement came after a recent chain of cases in Liberia was snuffed out, ending an epidemic that killed more than 11,300 people, mostly in West Africa.

headline: Care Differs for American and African With Ebola
abstract: The latest American aid worker to contract Ebola overseas was quickly transported back to the United States; the course of care has been markedly different for a Sierra Leonean colleague who developed Ebola within days of the American.

headline: Ebola Outbreak Erodes Recent Advances in West Africa
abstract: Ebola is wiping away the small gains made in war-scarred parts of West Africa, potentially threatening the hard-won stability in a tinderbox part of the world.

headline: Red Cross Faces Attacks at Ebola Victims’ Funerals
abstract: The International Federation of Red Cross and Red Crescent Societies reported Thursday that its burial teams in Guinea have been attacked verbally or physically 10 times a month on average since March.

headline: New Cases of Ebola Put an End to Liberia’s Status as Virus-Free
abstract: The body of a teenager tested positive for the virus, ending Liberia’s Ebola-free status, said the deputy minister for health, and raising fresh concerns.

headline: Beijing Donates $6 Million for Food Aid in Ebola Fight
abstract: China, a leading trading partner to many African countries, has been urged to take a more active role in the Ebola fight.

headline: Obama Hosts West African Leaders
abstract: The president met with the leaders of the Ebola-affected nations of Liberia, Sierra Leone and Guinea on Wednesday to discuss how the United States could help them as they rebuild after the outbreak.

headline: Liberia Reports New Cases of Ebola
abstract: Three cases have emerged in the country since it was declared free of the virus on May 9, highlighting the continuing threat of viral outbreaks in West Africa.

headline: Italian Nurse Who Worked in Sierra Leone Tests Positive for Ebola
abstract: The nurse, who was admitted to an infectious disease hospital in Rome, returned home last week after working in Sierra Leone.

headline: W.H.O. Issues New Guidelines on Safely Burying Ebola Victims
abstract: Victims are at their most infectious when they die, so the agency has tried to balance safety with the cultural sensitivities that surround traditional burial rites.

headline: U.S. Clinician With Ebola Under Care in Maryland
abstract: An American aid worker was infected while working in Sierra Leone, and he may have exposed colleagues in West Africa to the virus.

headline: Heart-Rending Test in Ebola Zone: A Baby
abstract: In a country devastated by a terrible disease, what to do when the task is caring for an hours-old baby whose mother might have died of Ebola?

headline: Australian Nurse Is Found Not to Have Ebola
abstract: The nurse, who developed a fever after she returned from Sierra Leone, where she had worked with Ebola patients, tested negative, health officials said.

headline: New Clues Into Ebola as Ill Nurse Improves
abstract: Pauline Cafferkey has been treated with an experimental anti-viral compound that is thought to work by incorporating itself into the genetic material while the Ebola virus is being copied.

headline: Ebola Spread Has Slowed in Liberia, C.D.C. Says
abstract: The international response to the epidemic, coupled with more effective action by local communities, has stopped its exponential spread in Liberia, the agency said.

headline: Small Rise in New Cases Shows Ebola Hanging On
abstract: A weekly increase in new cases, the first this year, was worrisome because some of them were patients who had not been listed for monitoring, health officials said.

headline: Withdrawing Troops, Obama Calls for Vigilance on Ebola
abstract: President Obama said that most American military personnel working to fight Ebola in West Africa would soon come home, but that the disease had the potential to flare again.

headline: In Liberia, a Good or Very Bad Sign: Empty Hospital Beds
abstract: Liberia has far fewer people being treated for Ebola than anticipated, but health officials are hesitant to declare victory.

headline: The Last Place on Earth With Ebola: Getting Guinea to Zero
abstract: The deadliest Ebola epidemic in history has come down to a handful of cases in a cluster of villages, but efforts to end the outbreak have been uneven at best.

headline: Britain: Ebola Case Reported in Glasgow
abstract: A woman who had been working in Sierra Leone was being treated Monday for Ebola in a Glasgow hospital.

headline: Ebola Outbreak Could Be Ended by Summer, U.N. Says
abstract: Dr. Bruce Aylward said the crisis could be stopped completely, but only if funding continues and health workers can build trust in wary communities.

headline: New Ebola Cases May Soon Reach 10,000 a Week, Officials Predict
abstract: The World Health Organization warned that the spread of the disease could become unmanageable and renew risks of political instability in fragile countries.

headline: Ebola Researchers Take New Look at Risk of Sexual Transmission
abstract: Responding to suspected cases of male Ebola survivors infecting partners, scientists are investigating how long the virus can remain in semen.

headline: Braving Ebola
abstract: The men and women of one Ebola clinic in rural Liberia reflect on life inside the gates.

headline: A Chinese Ebola Drug Raises Hopes, and Rancor
abstract: The production of an experimental Ebola treatment by a small Chinese company has led to patent infringement claims by American officials and disagreements among doctors.

headline: Liberia, Ravaged by Ebola, Faces a Future Without It
abstract: The West African nation, which is improving its health care systems, now has Ebola under control after being overwhelmed by the disease last year.

headline: In Sierra Leone, Giving the Stigma of Ebola a Good, Swift Kick
abstract: An all-survivors soccer team led by Erison Turay was made to bring Ebola survivors together and create a new community from the shared pain of the past.

headline: Ebola Ravages Economies in West Africa
abstract: In Sierra Leone, Guinea and Liberia, Ebola is not just affecting immune systems but also the bottom lines of businesses and governments.

headline: Officials Say Ebola Cases Are Falling In West Africa
abstract: Officials said that there had been a substantial reduction in new cases, but that dwindling funds and the approaching rainy season were a problem.

headline: W.H.O. Chief Calls Ebola Outbreak a ‘Crisis for International Peace’
abstract: The virus’s spread in West Africa is “unquestionably the most severe acute public health emergency in modern times,” said Dr. Margaret Chan, the body’s director general.

headline: Ebola Patient Is Moved to London, and 2 Others Are Tested in Britain
abstract: The patient in the confirmed case in Scotland had worked with a charity in Sierra Leone. Officials were testing two others, in Scotland and England, for the disease.

headline: Liberian Leader Concedes Errors in Response to Ebola
abstract: President Ellen Johnson Sirleaf acknowledged on Wednesday that she had made a mistake in ordering a tough security crackdown at the height of the Ebola crisis last year.

headline: West Africans Make Plea for Long List of Ebola Needs
abstract: The presidents of Guinea, Liberia and Sierra Leone, the nations most affected by the Ebola outbreak, made their case at a meeting of the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund in Washington.

headline: Ebola Patient in Dallas Lied on Screening Form, Liberian Airport Official Says
abstract: Thomas E. Duncan, the Liberian who developed Ebola symptoms after arriving in Dallas, lied about his history of contact with the disease on a questionnaire, an official said.

headline: Britain Pledges Millions to Fight Ebola and Chides Others to Spend More
abstract: Prime Minister David Cameron of Britain said his country had already promised more aid than any other in Europe to fight Ebola in West Africa, but said, “we need other European countries to do more.”

headline: Ebola Cases Fall Sharply, W.H.O. Reports
abstract: The number of new Ebola diagnoses in Sierra Leone and Guinea reached its lowest point in well over a year last week, according to the World Health Organization.

headline: Ebola, Thief of Rituals, Leaves No Graves to Decorate
abstract: Decoration Day is for sprucing up burial sites and celebrating life, but after 3,000 bodies were cremated because of the Ebola outbreak, Wednesday’s holiday was a somber affair.

headline: Sierra Leone to Eclipse Liberia in Ebola Cases
abstract: The World Health Organization reported more than 600 new cases of Ebola in the week that ended Sunday, more than half of them in Sierra Leone.

headline: Denial and Disconnect Add to Toll of Ebola in Sierra Leone
abstract: Persistent denial has been harmful to the fight against the virus in African nations, as has officials’ apparent lack of awareness of the extent of the desperation and death.

headline: Surge of Ebola in Liberia May Be Linked to a Survivor
abstract: The conclusion was made by scientists who analyzed the genetic sequence of the virus from the body of a Liberian boy who died of Ebola last week.

headline: In Europe, Fear of Ebola Exceeds the Actual Risks
abstract: Across the Continent, as in the United States, the virus has stirred a wave of alarm that, according to experts, reflects the insecurities of the modern mind far more than any significant danger to public health.

headline: As Ebola Rages, Poor Planning Thwarts Efforts
abstract: Aid officials in Sierra Leone say weak coordination among aid groups, government mismanagement and glaring inefficiencies are costing countless lives.

headline: Nearly Halted in Sierra Leone, Ebola Makes Comeback by Sea
abstract: Sierra Leone thought it had beaten back the disease, then two fishing boats carrying three infected mariners arrived at a wharf in February.

headline: Nigeria Is Free of Ebola, Health Agency Affirms
abstract: The announcement called Nigeria’s effort a “spectacular success story” but warned that the country, Africa’s most populous, cannot relax its defenses.

headline: Ebola Slowing in Liberia, W.H.O. Says, but International Support Is Still Necessary
abstract: The World Health Organization’s assistant director general said there had been a decline in burials in the West African nation and no increases in confirmed cases.

headline: One Year Later, Ebola Outbreak Offers Lessons for Next Epidemic
abstract: While the disease has not been eliminated, aid groups take stock of what worked and didn’t, and continue to point fingers.

headline: Ebola Prompts North Korea to Bar Tourists
abstract: The country said it was stepping up inspections and quarantine measures at its airport, borders and ports to guard against the spread of the deadly virus.

headline: As Ebola Ebbs in Africa, Focus Turns From Death to Life
abstract: New cases in Liberia, where streets were littered with the Ebola dead just a few months ago at the height of the epidemic, now number in the single digits, according to the World Health Organization.

headline: Condition of Spanish Nurse With Ebola Worsens, Officials Say
abstract: The deterioration came as the authorities announced that one more health care worker had been quarantined, in addition to three others who were isolated overnight.

headline: C.D.C. Head Says Fight on Ebola Will Be Long
abstract: Dr. Thomas R. Frieden, back from a weeklong trip to West Africa, said he saw hopeful signs in Guinea and Liberia, but there was ample reason for continued concern.

headline: Last Known Ebola Patient in Liberia Is Discharged
abstract: Beatrice Yardolo lost two sons and a daughter to the disease, but she gave thanks to God as she returned home to the rest of her family.

headline: Liberia President, Citing Ebola Gains, Ends State of Emergency
abstract: President Ellen Johnson Sirleaf said she would not extend the state of emergency, which had angered critics.

headline: Free of Ebola, Nurse’s Aide Leaves Spanish Hospital
abstract: María Teresa Romero Ramos, 44, was found to be infected with the virus after treating a Spanish missionary who had returned from West Africa with the disease.

headline: New Concerns Over Response to Ebola Crisis
abstract: Doctors Without Borders, which responded early to the outbreak in West Africa, said local doctors, nurses and charity workers were still carrying an inordinate burden.

headline: Liberia Conquers Ebola, but Faces a Crisis of Faith
abstract: Churches have been holding special prayers, revivals and workshops, with the purpose of refastening ties frayed by Ebola, a disease that made many fear those closest to them.

headline: Sierra Leone Prognosis Is ‘Very Good’
abstract: A World Health Organization assistant director general, Dr. Bruce Aylward, said the prognosis for Ebola in Sierra Leone is “very good” because of plans for building more treatment centers there.

headline: Demands for an Explanation Grow After a Nurse in Spain Contracts Ebola
abstract: The nurse’s husband and two other people were quarantined, and monitoring was extended to 50 other people who might have come into contact with her.

headline: Experimental Ebola Vaccine Tested in Guinea Shows Promise, Report Says
abstract: The report, published in the British medical journal The Lancet, indicated that the vaccine “might be safe and highly efficacious in preventing Ebola virus disease.”

headline: Mali Reports First Death From Ebola
abstract: The death of a 2-year-old girl who traveled across two countries while showing symptoms of Ebola is the first recorded Ebola death in Mali.

headline: Officials Cite Error With Gloves in Spanish Case of Ebola
abstract: Spanish health officials began to explain Wednesday how an auxiliary nurse became the first Ebola case in Western Europe.

headline: Getting to Zero Ebola Cases
abstract: On Saturday, the World Health Organization declared Liberia free of Ebola.

headline: Effort on Ebola Hurt W.H.O. Chief
abstract: Critics of Margaret Chan have said she lets governments around the world steer the W.H.O. to fit their own needs, instead of firmly taking the helm as the world’s doctor in chief.

headline: North Korea Said to Impose Ebola Quarantine on All Travelers
abstract: North Korea, which in the best of times allows a limited number of people in or out, is so rattled by the virus that it reportedly will quarantine anyone coming into the country from anywhere.

headline: Pattern of Safety Lapses Where Group Worked to Battle Ebola Outbreak
abstract: Safety deficiencies at a treatment center staffed by Partners in Health, a charity that pledged to fight Ebola in Sierra Leone and Liberia, led to the closure of the center after two clinicians were diagnosed with Ebola.

headline: U.S. Aid Effort in Liberia Barely Off the Ground as Ebola Rages
abstract: The American promise to build 18 Ebola treatment centers has been stalled by, among other things, broken equipment and numerous holes on an airport runway.

headline: Despite Aid Push, Ebola Is Raging in Sierra Leone
abstract: After calling for an ambulance more than 35 times, a family in Sierra Leone, where Ebola has hit harder than in neighboring countries, waited for three days for help to arrive.

headline: European Leaders Scramble to Upgrade Response to Ebola Crisis
abstract: Europe has suffered a blow to its self-image of generosity, its efforts to contain Ebola overshadowed  by President Obama’s announcement that he was sending  3,000 troops to West Africa.

headline: Treating Those Treating Ebola in Liberia
abstract: A dedicated Ebola field hospital for health workers is scheduled to open Friday in Monrovia, Liberia, as part of an effort to ease the worries of would-be volunteers.

headline: An Ebola Orphan’s Plea in Africa: ‘Do You Want Me?’
abstract: After her mother died of Ebola, a young girl in Sierra Leone was left an orphan when nobody in her village, even relatives, wanted to take her, though she showed no symptoms of the virus.

headline: W.H.O. Needs Reforms in Wake of Ebola Crisis, Report Says
abstract: A panel of experts said that the World Health Organization requires a radical change of culture to cope with future emergencies.

headline: Ebola Patient Dies in German Hospital
abstract: The Sudanese man, who had been working with the United Nations in Liberia, was the third patient to arrive in Germany in recent weeks for treatment, and the first to die.

headline: Spain Exposes Holes in Plans to Treat Ebola
abstract: Madrid, where a nurse contracted the disease, mostly dismantled its infectious disease center as part of a government cost-cutting plan.

headline: U.S. Patient Aided Pregnant Liberian, Then Took Ill
abstract: Senior Liberian officials said the man, Thomas Eric Duncan from Monrovia, had helped a woman who had Ebola to the hospital a few days before he left for the United States.

headline: Back to School, Though Not Back to Normal, in a Liberia Still Fearful of Ebola
abstract: Ebola cases have receded into the single digits in Liberia, but fear of the virus and a depressed economy have dampened a back-to-school campaign.

headline: Sierra Leone Detains Journalist for Criticism of Ebola Response
abstract: David Tam-Baryoh devoted a segment of his radio program to a critical discussion of President Ernest Bai Koroma’s handling of the outbreak.

headline: W.H.O. Leader Outlines Changes in Response to Ebola Epidemic
abstract: The World Health Organization must act to ensure it will not be caught flat-footed by future crises, Dr. Margaret Chan said at the start of a 10-day meeting.

headline: E.U. Urges States to Coordinate Efforts to Cut Risk of Importing Ebola
abstract: The top health minister called for the sharing of real-time information about airline and railroad passenger movements within the union.

headline: For a Liberian Family, Ebola Turns Loving Care Into Deadly Risk
abstract: The Doryen family, unbowed survivors of Liberia’s civil war, saw seven members die from the virus in a matter of months and lost its sense of unity.

headline: As Ebola Spreads, Asia Senses Vulnerability
abstract: Senior officials in China and India have been scrambling to prepare their countries' medical systems to cope with possible cases.

headline: W.H.O. Promises Reform After Criticism Over Ebola Response
abstract: The World Health Organization acknowledged it was not prepared to deal with the Ebola outbreak, and vowed to overhaul the way it handles epidemics.

headline: Obama Nominates Gayle Smith to Lead U.S.A.I.D.
abstract: Ms. Smith, who is well-known in Washington development circles, would be in charge of the government’s response to humanitarian disasters and manage the agency’s $20 billion budget.

headline: Ebola Fight in Africa Is Hurt by Limits on Ways to Get Out
abstract: The lack of a reliable evacuation system makes aid missions to West Africa much more dangerous for volunteers, who are thus less likely to go there.

headline: Doctors Without Borders Evolves as It Forms the Vanguard in Ebola Fight
abstract: How the group could do what no one else accomplished in West Africa is explained in part by its self-reliance and a focus on innovation.

headline: Ebola Survivors Face Lingering Pain, Fatigue and Depression
abstract: About half the survivors seem to have chronic joint pain that is often severe enough to prevent them from working, an expert said.

headline: Liberian President’s Ban on Rallies Is Seen as Political
abstract: Critics say a decree by President Ellen Johnson Sirleaf of Liberia that bans all political rallies in Monrovia to prevent the further spread of Ebola is really an attempt to ensure victory for her son’s Senate campaign.

headline: Few Liberians Turn Out for Vote Delayed by Ebola
abstract: Extra cardboard dividers and ballot boxes were added at polling places to minimize the risk of voters contracting Ebola, which is spread through physical contact.

headline: Inquiry Faults Liberia Force That Fired on Protesters
abstract: An independent human rights panel found that Liberian security forces fired directly into a crowd of civilians who were protesting a quarantine this summer.

headline: In Layers of Gear, Offering Healing Hand to Ebola Patients in Liberia
abstract: Doctors offer Ebola patients simple comforts, like feeding them or cleaning them up. But they also try to restrain their own impulses, because old habits might not be safe.

headline: Officials Admit a ‘Defeat’ by Ebola in Sierra Leone
abstract: The decision to help families treat patients at home signifies a significant shift in the struggle against the rampaging disease.

headline: Ebola Infects Spanish Nurse, a First in West
abstract: The nurse was the first health worker to be infected with the virus outside West Africa, raising concerns about how prepared Western nations are to treat Ebola victims.

headline: Genome Studies Show How Ebola Spread Initially
abstract: Scientists have developed a fuller picture of how the virus spread and evolved by tracking mutations in its genome.

headline: Health Officials Reassess Strategy to Combat Ebola in Liberia
abstract: As the rate of new infections has slowed, American and Liberian officials are debating whether to shift money that was planned for the centers into other programs to combat future outbreaks.

headline: Liberian Court Rejects Petition to Delay Elections Over Ebola
abstract: Liberia’s Supreme Court on Saturday said it would not halt Senate elections scheduled for Tuesday, but the ultimate day of the vote remains unclear.

headline: Life, Death and Grim Routine Fill the Day at a Liberian Ebola Clinic
abstract: Health workers tend to people sickened by Ebola and those quarantined while they wait to learn if they have the virus.

headline: A Hospital From Hell, in a City Swamped by Ebola
abstract: Ebola is sweeping into areas of West Africa that had been largely spared the onslaught. The consequences in one Sierra Leone hospital have been devastating.

headline: No Moon Suits, Just Trunks and the Healing Surf
abstract: As Ebola gnaws through Sierra Leone, those at Bureh Beach Surf Club teach and feed tourists, eking out a living seemingly determined to pursue their passion as a way to cope.

headline: Ebola Help for Sierra Leone Is Nearby, but Delayed on the Docks
abstract: More than $140,000 worth of medical supplies have been locked inside a dented container at the port in Freetown, Sierra Leone, since Aug. 9.

headline: Botswana Doctor Is Named to Lead W.H.O. in Africa
abstract: The much-praised appointee, Dr. Matshidiso Moeti, promised to overhaul the regional office, which has faced criticism for its slow response to the Ebola crisis.

headline: Palm Oil Company Is Accused of Exploiting Liberia’s Ebola Crisis
abstract: During the height of the Ebola outbreak, a community signed over large swaths of farming land. Now, some are questioning the benefits, and ethics, of the deal.

headline: Ebola Response in Liberia Is Hampered by Infighting
abstract: Poor coordination and serious disagreements between Liberian officials and the donors and health agencies fighting the epidemic are hindering results.

headline: Ebola’s Cultural Casualty: Hugs in Hands-On Liberia
abstract: As Ebola ravages West Africa, Liberians are losing an integral part of their culture, in which the double-cheek kiss was once the standard greeting.

headline: Liberia’s Ebola Crisis Puts President in Harsh Light
abstract: As Liberia’s first elected leader after a devastating civil war, President Ellen Johnson Sirleaf has pushed the country to economic growth, but gains have been halted by the Ebola outbreak.

headline: Wish to Do More in Ebola Fight Meets Reality in Liberia
abstract: Health workers in Liberia and elsewhere in West Africa are finding they have to ration care, operating under constraints they often find frustrating.

headline: Ambulance Work in Liberia Is a Busy and Lonely Business
abstract: Only about 15 ambulance teams are available to aid Monrovia, a city of nearly 1.5 million people, where hundreds of new Ebola cases are reported each week.

headline: They Helped Erase Ebola in Liberia. Now Liberia Is Erasing Them.
abstract: Thirty young men spent months burning the bodies of the infected. A year later, many relatives and fellow countrymen still can’t forgive them.

headline: Panels Advise Bolstering W.H.O. for Crises Like Ebola
abstract: Both groups said that the United Nations health agency’s outbreak and emergency response capacities should be strengthened, and protected from political meddling.

headline: Ebola, Ruthless to Families, Leaves Liberian Man Alive and Alone
abstract: Gaye Dumbai got the news that greets so many other survivors: His relatives — 13 in all — were dead. Now, more than a year later, he has his life back, but it is not the same life.

headline: Liberia’s Military Tries to Remedy Tension Over Ebola Quarantine
abstract: As residents of a slum in the capital were trapped behind barricades in August, riots erupted, soldiers fired shots and a teenager was fatally wounded.

headline: In Homeland, Liberia Native Finds Resilience Amid Horror
abstract: Long before Ebola arrived, the people of Liberia endured 14 years of civil war. When it finally ended in 2003, what was left was a nation of survivors.

headline: W.H.O. Members Endorse Resolution to Improve Response to Health Emergencies
abstract: Key provisions include creating a global cadre of emergency health workers, establishing a fund that could be tapped quickly, and support for the development of treatments for emerging infectious diseases.

headline: W.H.O. Members Endorse Resolution to Improve Response to Health Emergencies
abstract: Key provisions include creating a global cadre of emergency health workers, establishing a fund that could be tapped quickly, and support for the development of treatments for emerging infectious diseases.

headline: Liberia Lifts Its Curfew, but Border Stays Sealed
abstract: Sierra Leonean authorities said Sunday that they had received no instructions to open their side of the border with Liberia, sealed in late July to try to limit the spread of the Ebola virus.

headline: Global Response to Ebola Highlights Challenges in Delivering Aid
abstract: As medical teams head to Sierra Leone, a Doctors Without Borders director says a reliance on volunteers, without military aid in setting up facilities, remains a roadblock.

headline: W.H.O. to Focus on Containing Ebola in Africa
abstract: The World Health Organization will concentrate on 15 African countries with communications and trade links with Guinea, Liberia and Sierra Leone, an official said.

headline: Fear of Ebola Opens Wary Villages to Outsiders in Guinea
abstract: In Guinea’s Forest Region, villages that have refused outside help to fight the Ebola outbreak are starting to soften their resistance.

headline: Amid Ebola Crisis, Liberian Army Sees Its Chance at Rebranding
abstract: The Liberian Army, working alongside American troops, has become a linchpin in the fight against the Ebola virus. But it faces a wary public.

headline: Pursuing a Calling That Leads to West Africa
abstract: Dr. Steven Hatch of the University of Massachusetts medical school explains what led him to volunteer at an Ebola clinic in Suakoko, Liberia.

headline: Handful of Liberians Running to Prove a Point About Ebola
abstract: After eradicating Ebola, the Liberian Marathon (all 13 miles of it) returned this year to remind the world that the country was healthy and back to form.

headline: Ebola’s Mystery: One Boy Lives, Another Dies
abstract: Over and over, doctors have been confounded by the divergent paths of Ebola patients whose cases appeared similar at first.

headline: U.N. Rights Chief Warns Against Anti-African Discrimination Over Ebola
abstract: Zeid Ra’ad al-Hussein, the new chief, warned against ill-conceived quarantines. He also said his agency needed more money to combat multiple crises.

headline: W.H.O. Sets Up Global Response Unit
abstract: The World Health Organization says it has set up a unit to fight the microcephaly outbreak in Latin America linked to the Zika virus, using the lessons learned from the Ebola crisis.

headline: Partnership Aims to Bolster Local Health Care Providers
abstract: A collaboration of the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation, the World Bank and the World Health Organization will focus on medical care in poor and middle-income countries.

headline: North Korea Reopens Borders in Time for Marathon
abstract: To race on Pyongyang’s streets, runners will need to sign up through a package tour offered by companies outside North Korea and will have to fly through China.

headline: Liberia: Soccer Star Leads Senate Race
abstract: The former soccer star George Weah appeared to have won a landslide victory in a Senate race that pitted him against the president’s son, Robert Sirleaf.

headline: Brazil to Keep Allowances for the Poor
abstract: Despite Brazil’s budget problems, there will be no cuts in a pioneering and widely admired program of monthly cash allowances to the poor.

headline: Looking Past Africa's Turmoil
abstract: The perception of Africa as a collection of dystopian states and regions persists, but there are signs of a subtle shift.

headline: In Travel Out of Liberia, Nothing Is Simply Routine
abstract: A reporter takes the same route from Liberia to the United States as Thomas Eric Duncan, the man who, after traveling on to Dallas, fell to the disease.

headline: Obama Could Replace Aides Bruised by a Cascade of Crises
abstract: Stumbles in the handling of the Ebola crisis and the Islamic State have fueled speculation that President Obama may shake up his foreign policy team.

headline: Suspect Is Held in Killing of American in Abu Dhabi
abstract: The interior minister of the United Arab Emirates said the suspect had also planted a bomb on the doorstep of an Egyptian-American doctor.

headline: Guinea President’s Re-election Confirmed Despite Fraud Complaints
abstract: A judicial panel that reviewed claims of fraud in the Oct. 11 election certified that the incumbent, Alpha Condé, had won nearly 58 percent of the vote.

headline: 15 of the Best Journals by Our Reporters Around the World
abstract: Journals, a fixture of the international section, allow correspondents to step back from the news and write about places that intrigue them. We hope you enjoy our choices.

headline: Australia to Begin Monitoring for Zika Virus
abstract: Health officials in the northern part of Queensland and Papua New Guinea, to Australia’s north, have begun taking measures to guard against the virus.

headline: Putin Accuses U.S. of Backing ‘Neo-Fascists’ and ‘Islamic Radicals’
abstract: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia unleashed perhaps his strongest diatribe against the United States yet.

headline: War, Disease and Scandals Test Soccer Chief in Sierra Leone
abstract: Isha Johansen, the president of Sierra Leone’s soccer association, is one of just a handful of women in the world to have held such a post.

headline: North Korea Executed 15 Top Officials in 2015, South Korean Agency Says
abstract: The tally adds to 68 believed to be killed between 2012-14, as Kim Jong-un tries to assert his authority, a South Korean spy agency told lawmakers in Seoul.

headline: U.S. Embassy Describes Coup Attempt in Gambia
abstract: The Gambian government insisted that “peace and calm” prevailed after gunfire erupted overnight in the capital, Banjul.

headline: National Security Adviser Meets With Chinese President Before His U.S. Visit
abstract: Susan E. Rice met with President Xi Jinping and other officials and discussed a number of issues that included areas of tension between the two nations.

headline: U.S.-Owned Plane Carrying Corpse and Cash Is Impounded in Zimbabwe
abstract: The cargo jet, transporting money for the South African Reserve Bank, was seized during a refueling stop after a body dripping blood was found on board.

headline: Fearing the Tide in West Point, a Slum Already Swamped With Worry
abstract: About 75,000 Monrovia residents await word on whether infrastructure will be improved to withstand the sea, or if they will be relocated.

headline: North Korea May Have a Missionary in Custody
abstract: The chief pastor from a Korean church in Toronto had failed to return home from a humanitarian mission to the North.

headline: Guinea President Set to Win Re-election, as Opponents Allege Voter Fraud
abstract: Protesters against President Alpha Condé have clashed with the police even before the results are announced of Sunday’s vote, which observers said was poorly run but largely fair.

headline: Journalists Facing Biggest Threats in Recent Times, Advocacy Group Says
abstract: An annual report by the Committee to Protect Journalists said the threats, from nonstate actors and governments, were especially acute for freelancers.

headline: Unicef Calls 2014 One of Worst Years for Children
abstract: Up to 15 million children are directly entangled in violent conflicts, mostly in the Middle East and Africa, a report by the group said.

headline: U.S. Policy Makers Could See Opportunity in China’s Rise
abstract: “It would be a mistake to view increased frictions as the result of inattention or clumsy policy,” says Ely Ratner, deputy director of the Asia-Pacific Security Program at the Center for a New American Security.

headline: Father of Drowned Syrian Boy Delivers Christmas Message to Britons
abstract: Britain’s Channel 4 will broadcast a recorded message from Abdullah Kurdi, the Syrian refugee whose young son drowned off Turkey in September, on Christmas Day.

headline: Obama Offers Assurances of U.S. Shift Toward Asia
abstract: Visiting Australia, President Obama said the United States could be a force for order as Asia faced threats like a nuclear-armed North Korea and disputes between China and its neighbors.

headline: Part of Sierra Leone’s History Is Being Dismantled Board by Board
abstract: Freetown’s board houses are as old as the city itself, but they are fast disappearing amid rapid urbanization and a growing preference for concrete.

headline: Western Relations Frosty, Russia Warms to North Korea
abstract: On Wednesday, the Russian Foreign Ministry announced an agreement to designate 2015 as a “Year of Friendship” with North Korea.

headline: Unicef, Seeking More Aid, Points to Children Touched by Armed Conflict
abstract: The agency is asking for $3.1 billion, one-third more than it did last year, with the goal of helping 62 million children in 71 countries.

headline: Merkel to Attack Anti-Immigrant Movement in Germany
abstract: The German chancellor will use her New Year’s speech to urge people not to join the weekly protests in Dresden held by Patriotic Europeans Against the Islamization of the West.

headline: Street-Level Views of the Protests in Burkina Faso
abstract: Video posted on YouTube offered vivid glimpses of the demonstrators who forced Burkina Faso’s longtime president, Blaise Compaoré, from office.

headline: Zika Vaccine Still Years Away, W.H.O. Says
abstract: Despite efforts to speed up development, a vaccine to combat the virus may come too late for the current outbreak in Latin America and the Caribbean, health experts said.

headline: South Korea Confirms 2 More Deaths in MERS Outbreak
abstract: Two men, ages 82 and 76, were the country’s latest victims of an illness that has forced over 1,160 schools and kindergartens to shut down temporarily.

headline: Francis, in Christmas Day Message, Focuses on Children in Peril
abstract: Vast numbers of children today are victims of violence, objects of trade and trafficking, or forced to become soldiers, he said.

headline: Calls Grow to Broaden Search for Next U.N. Leader
abstract: With Ban Ki-moon set to step down in 2016, momentum is building to open up the secretive selection process for the next United Nations secretary general.

headline: Chinese Fleets Illegally Fish in West African Waters, Greenpeace Says
abstract: A study by the group accuses hundreds of Chinese-owned or Chinese-flagged vessels of taking advantage of weak enforcement by African governments.

headline: Conflict, and Smiles, as U.S. and Cuba Discuss Ties
abstract: The sides met for several hours, mostly to iron out technical issues in converting their diplomatic outposts into full-fledged embassies.

headline: Taiwan and Hainan at Risk of Zika Spread, Scientist Warns
abstract: The two islands both have populations of the Aedes aegypti mosquito, which is believed to be the main carrier of the virus.

headline: Obama Tackles Poverty and Sexism in U.N. Speech
abstract: Calling for better treatment of women around the world as he addressed the General Assembly, President Obama said he had no patience for excuses about discrimination.

headline: Submarine Search Near Stockholm Reminiscent of a Cold War Thriller
abstract: Sweden launched a search team of 200 personnel aboard ships, helicopters and minesweepers to scour the Baltic Sea in search of an unidentified foreign vessel.

headline: U.S. and Russia Agree to Share More Intelligence on ISIS
abstract: Secretary of State John Kerry made it clear that he would welcome expanded cooperation with Russia after a meeting in Paris with the country’s foreign minister.

headline: U.N. Agency Hires Wife of Top Figure in Syrian War to Assist the Displaced
abstract: Shukria Mekdad’s appointment has led critics to question the World Health Organization’s impartiality, as her husband is a defender of the government’s war effort.

headline: An Inconvenient Protest for Both China and the U.S.
abstract: Demonstrations in Hong Kong put the Obama administration in the awkward position of wanting to support pro-democracy forces without alienating a key partner.

headline: For China and Japan, a New Effort to Improve Relations Produces a Chilly Scene
abstract: The encounter between President Xi Jinping of China and Prime Minister Shinzo Abe of Japan was aimed at moving away from a standoff between the countries.

headline: Saudis Are Next on Biden’s Mideast Apology List After Harvard Remarks
abstract: The vice president’s problems began Thursday when he declared that the biggest problem in dealing with Syria and the rise of the Islamic State was America’s allies in the region.

headline: For Obama and Indian Leader, a Friendly Stroll if Not a Full Embrace
abstract: The White House tried to spotlight hopes for working with Prime Minister Narendra Modi while not lavishing full pageantry on a leader who was once barred from entering the United States.

headline: To China, Shift in Obama’s Political Fortunes Eclipses U.S. Economic Gains
abstract: When President Obama visits China on Monday, authorities there are likely to dwell more on his electoral reversals than on the robust American economy, analysts say.

headline: Finishing Asia Tour, Obama Promotes More Ambitious Foreign Policy
abstract: The scorecard for President Obama’s Asia trip looks drastically different from the last one, with a landmark climate-change agreement and a trade deal with China.

headline: At Auschwitz, a Summer Precaution Is a Grim Reminder to Some
abstract: Critics said overhead sprinklers at the entrance to the death camp’s memorial and museum were reminiscent of the showers the Nazis used to gas Jews in World War II.

headline: Roberto Gómez Bolaños, Mexico’s Comedic Artist ‘Chespirito,’ Dies at 85
abstract: The actor, writer and director was known around the Spanish-speaking world for his iconic characters and widely viewed television shows.

headline: Polio Crisis Deepens in Pakistan, With New Cases and Killings
abstract: The number of new Pakistani polio cases this year has hit 260, four times as many as last year, and four more anti-polio workers have been killed in the field.

headline: Qaeda Rampage in Burkina Faso Shakes Service Employees
abstract: Hotel and restaurant workers in the African nation’s capital were left feeling vulnerable after an attack claimed 29 lives on Friday.

headline: Poor in Guinea, but Making a Living From Crisp New Banknotes
abstract: The demand for crisp, clean Guinean francs for gift giving has provided jobs for young people in Conakry, who try to reel in customers wanting to trade in old bills.

headline: Despite Cuts, U.S. Army Prepares for Threats in Europe
abstract: Across-the-board spending cuts are squeezing the Pentagon’s budget, while a war-weary nation is showing little eagerness to sustain a global, war-ready crouch.

headline: Britain’s Drift From the Global Stage Becomes an Election Issue
abstract: There is growing concern that Britain is ceding its reputation for “punching above its weight” when it comes to matters like Ukraine and the Middle East, and even its alliance with the United States.

headline: Making Merkel Wait, Finding Time for Truffles
abstract: President Vladimir V. Putin kept Chancellor Angela Merkel waiting for hours, met after 2 a.m. with Silvio Berlusconi, and joked at a news conference, but budged little on the Ukraine crisis.

headline: Bloc in Europe Starts to Balk Over Austerity
abstract: Many of the largest European countries, including France and Italy, are now rebelling against the German gospel of belt-tightening and calling for more radical steps to reverse their slumping fortunes.

headline: Russia Uses Money and Ideology to Fight Western Sanctions
abstract: Moscow is leveraging its economic power, financing European political parties and movements, and spreading alternative accounts of the conflict.

headline: U.N. Set to Cut Force in Darfur as Fighting Rises
abstract: United Nations officials say their forces are routinely attacked by Sudanese forces and their proxies and that it is virtually impossible for their peacekeepers to remain without Sudan’s blessing.

headline: A Ukrainian Border Town Once Fenced by Soviets Blossoms Into a Shopper’s Paradise
abstract: Since 2005, a pedestrian crossing has drawn a surge of Slovakian visitors to a small Ukrainian village, where consumer goods are considerably cheaper.

headline: Obama and Putin Play Diplomatic Poker Over Syria
abstract: President Obama and President Vladimir V. Putin essentially blamed each other for the catastrophic war in Syria and the refugee crisis it spurred in their speeches at the General Assembly.

headline: President Obama’s Speech to the United Nations General Assembly 2015
abstract: The speech delivered by President Obama at the United Nations General Assembly as transcribed and released by the White House.
